Semi-asynchronous Hierarchical Federated Learning for Cooperative Intelligent Transportation Systems

Qimei Chen, Zehua You, and Hao Jiang Q. Chen, Z. You, and H. Jiang are with the School of Electronic Information, Wuhan University, Wuhan 430072, China (e-mail: {chenqimei; youzehua; jh}@whu.edu.cn)
Abstract

Cooperative Intelligent Transport System (C-ITS) is a promising network to provide safety, efficiency, sustainability, and comfortable services for automated vehicles and road infrastructures by taking advantages from participants. However, the components of C-ITS usually generate large amounts of data, which makes it difficult to explore data science. Currently, federated learning has been proposed as an appealing approach to allow users to cooperatively reap the benefits from trained participants. Therefore, in this paper, we propose a novel Semi-asynchronous Hierarchical Federated Learning (SHFL) framework for C-ITS that enables elastic edge to cloud model aggregation from data sensing. We further formulate a joint edge node association and resource allocation problem under the proposed SHFL framework to prevent personalities of heterogeneous road vehicles and achieve communication-efficiency. To deal with our proposed Mixed integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) problem, we introduce a distributed Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM)-Block Coordinate Update (BCU) algorithm. With this algorithm, a tradeoff between training accuracy and transmission latency has been derived. Numerical results demonstrate the advantages of the proposed algorithm in terms of training overhead and model performance.

Index Terms:
C-ITS, federated learning, asynchronous, edge association, resource allocation.

I Introduction

With the rapid developments of automated vehicles and Internet-of-Vehicles, Cooperative Intelligent Transport Systems (C-ITS) is expected to provide safety, traffic efficiency, and comfortable infotainment services for vehicles with an accurate neighborhood view [1]. Specifically, the C-ITS components including vehicles, road infrastructure units, personal devices, and traffic command centers can achieve additional traffic management and convenience with the help of enhanced visions from surrounding participants [2].

Currently, both the Wireless Access in Vehicular Environments (WAVE) and the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI) standards have been proposed consecutively to define spectrum allocation, traffic parameters setting, and protocol stack to enable Quality-of-Service (QoS) and security procedure for C-ITS [3]. Several works have also studied the technologies for C-ITS. The authors in [4] introduce a choreography-based service composition platform to accelerate the reuse-based development for a choreography-based urban coordinative application. The authors in [5] proposed a novel topological graph convolutional network to predict the urban traffic flow and traffic density.

The authors in [6] analyze the relationship among security, QoS, and safety for vehicles in C-ITS. In addition, the authors in [7] investigate service-oriented cooperation models and mechanisms for autonomous vehicles in C-ITS. Nevertheless, they have neglected to explore the large amounts of traffic data generated from transportation sensor networks, which is essential for advanced C-ITS applications like connected and autonomous vehicles, traffic control and prediction, and road safety. Although some attempts have been made to utilize data science for C-ITS [8], there still exists various stuff challenges to be solved, such as privacy protection, computational complexity, and data heterogeneity.

With the significant advance cloud computing, big data, and machine learning, intelligent transportation is a trend and requirement. As one of the most dominant distributed machine learning technologies, Federated Learning (FL) has been widely studied to deal with the data science recently [9, 10, 11]. The FL technology allows participant devices to collaboratively build a shard model while preserving privacy data locally [12]. Particularly, the prevalent FL algorithm, namely federated averaging, allows each device to train a model locally with its own dataset, and then transmits the model parameters to the central controller for a global aggregation [13]. Intuitively, FL presents a great potential for C-ITS to facilitate the large data management. However, directly applying FL to C-ITS still faces three major deficiencies: 1) limited wireless resources; 2) high latency; 3) obliterated data diversity.

According to [18, 19], Federated Learning training at Edge networks (FEL) has been regarded as a solution to facilitate the above limitations through bringing model training closer to the data produced locally. Compared with the conventional cloud centric FL approaches, the implementation of FEL can provide high wireless resources utilization since less information is required to be transmitted to the cloud. In addition, FEL has a much lower transmission latency and higher privacy than the conventional FL by making decisions at the edge nodes. In [15], the authors develop an importance aware joint data selection and resource allocation algorithm to maximize the resource and learning efficiencies. Meanwhile, the authors in [16] propose an adaptive federated learning mechanism in resource constrained edge computing systems. Along the FEL, the authors in [17] propose a novel Hierarchical Federated Edge Learning (HFEL) framework, where edge servers deployed with base stations fixedly and can upload edge aggregation model to the cloud. The above HFEL enables great potentials in low latency and energy efficiency.

However, the participant C-ITS devices usually have heterogeneous resources, which lead to non-independent-identically distributed (non-iid) private data during the communication [20, 21]. The existing federated learning methods mainly utilize the synchronous model aggregation mechanism, where the central server needs to wait for the slowest device to complete the training in each communication round [14, 22]. With heterogeneous data, the transmission latency of each synchronous model aggregation mechanism is unacceptable for time-sensitive devices. In this way, several works have proposed asynchronous model aggregation methods, where only one participant device would update the global model each time [24, 25, 26]. Nonetheless, the training round under asynchronous methods is several times than that of synchronous methods. Moreover, due to the asynchrony, gradient staleness may be difficult to control [26]. Therefore, the authors in [23] design an n𝑛n-softsync aggregation model that can significantly reduce training time by combines the benefits of both synchronous and asynchronous aggregations.

Inspired by the above analyses, we aim to leverage a novel Semi-asynchronous Hierarchical Federated Learning (SHFL) framework that can provide safety, efficiency, sustainability, and comfortable services to C-ITS. Specifically, the proposed SHFL framework consists of both edge and cloud layers, where each edge node aggregates all of homogeneous local models and the cloud layer aggregates parts of heterogeneous edge models. These selected nodes would update the global model once the selected slowest node finishes training, which combines the merits of both synchronous and asynchronous aggregations. For further performance enhancement, we formulate a joint edge node association and resource allocation optimization problem to prevent heterogeneous edge node personalities as well as ensure communication-efficient of the whole system. The objective function is a Mixed Integer NonLinear Programming (MINLP) problem, which has been solved by a distributed Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM)-Block Coordinate Update (BCU) algorithm. It is shown that the proposed algorithm can achieve near optimal with low computational complexity. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work that applying improved FL into the C-ITS.

Overall, the main contributions of this work can be listed as follows.

  • •

    We propose a novel SHFL framework by applying the synchronous aggregation model for local-edge and the semi-asynchronous aggregation model for edge-cloud to provide safety, traffic efficiency, and comfortable infotainment services for C-ITS.

  • •

    To reserve the personalities of heterogeneous edge nodes, we introduce an elastic edge model update method based on the distance between the global model and the edge model.

  • •

    We formulate a joint edge node association and resource allocation problem to achieve communication-efficiency by achieving a tradeoff between training accuracy and transmission latency. A distributed ADMM-BCU algorithm has been used to solve the MINLP problem.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces the system model and the SHFL learning mechanism. In Section III, we formulate the communication-efficient problem. A joint edge node association and resource allocation strategy is presented in Section IV. Section V presents the numerical results, followed by the conclusions in Section VI.

II System Model

In this work, we aim to design a novel SHFL framework for C-ITS that contains three layers, namely the cloud layer, the edge layer, and the local layer, as shown in Fig. 1. Here, we consider the vehicle devices have heterogeneous data structures, namely the local datasets are non-iid. We let homogeneous devices with similar data size, network bandwidth, and QoS gather in the same edge node. Hence, the edge nodes are heterogeneous. A shared Deep Neural Network (DNN) model is distributed over the local devices, which has been trained collaboratively across the devices under their datasets. Different from conventional FLs, the proposed SHFL framework allows devices train their data locally, homogeneous devices report their computed parameters to the same edge node synchronously, and heterogeneous edge nodes upload their models to the cloud node semi-asynchronously, which can preserve data privacy as well as improve communication efficiency. In the proposed framework, we assume there has a set of K𝐾K edge nodes 𝒦={1,…,K}𝒦1…𝐾\mathcal{K}=\{1,...,K\}. Any edge node k𝑘k consists of a set of Nksubscript𝑁𝑘N_{k} local devices, denoted as 𝒩k={Lk,1,…,Lk,Nk}subscript𝒩𝑘subscript𝐿𝑘1…subscript𝐿𝑘subscript𝑁𝑘\mathcal{N}_{k}=\{L_{k,1},...,L_{k,N_{k}}\}. Under edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, local device n∈𝒩k𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘n\in\mathcal{N}_{k} owns a local data set Dk,n={(𝒙j,k,n,yj,k,n):j=1,…,|Dk,n|}subscript𝐷𝑘𝑛conditional-setsubscript𝒙𝑗𝑘𝑛subscript𝑦𝑗𝑘𝑛𝑗1…subscript𝐷𝑘𝑛D_{k,n}=\{(\boldsymbol{x}_{j,k,n},{y}_{j,k,n}):j=1,...,|D_{k,n}|\}, where 𝒙j,k,nsubscript𝒙𝑗𝑘𝑛\boldsymbol{x}_{j,k,n} is the j𝑗j-th input training data sample, yj,k,nsubscript𝑦𝑗𝑘𝑛{y}_{j,k,n} is the j𝑗j-th corresponding output, and |Dk,n|subscript𝐷𝑘𝑛|D_{k,n}| denotes the cardinality of the data set Dk,nsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑛D_{k,n}. For simplicity, we assume the SHFL algorithm with a single output. However, this work can be extended to the multiple outputs case. In what follows, we would introduce each part of the proposed SHFL framework at the t𝑡t-th iteration.

II-A Edge Aggregation

The edge aggregation stage contains three processes, including local model computation, local model transmission, and edge model aggregation. In detail, local model first trained by local data, then local models respectively transmit to their associated edge nodes for edge aggregation. The detailed processes are as follows.

II-A1 Local Model Computation

Without loss of generality, we consider a supervised machine learning task on device n∈𝒩k𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘n\in\mathcal{N}_{k} associated with edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, which has a learning model of 𝒘k,nsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑛\boldsymbol{w}_{k,n}. We further define fn​(𝒙j,k,n,yj,k,n,𝒘k,n)subscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝒙𝑗𝑘𝑛subscript𝑦𝑗𝑘𝑛subscript𝒘𝑘𝑛f_{n}(\boldsymbol{x}_{j,k,n},y_{j,k,n},\boldsymbol{w}_{k,n}) as the loss function of data sample j𝑗j that quantifies the prediction error between data sample 𝒙j,k,nsubscript𝒙𝑗𝑘𝑛\boldsymbol{x}_{j,k,n} and output yj,k,nsubscript𝑦𝑗𝑘𝑛y_{j,k,n}. In this work, we mainly focus on the logistic regression model for the loss function, i.e., fn​(𝒙j,k,n,yj,k,n,𝒘k,n)=−log⁡(1+exp⁡(−yj,k,n​𝒙j,k,nT​𝒘k,n))subscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝒙𝑗𝑘𝑛subscript𝑦𝑗𝑘𝑛subscript𝒘𝑘𝑛1subscript𝑦𝑗𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑗𝑘𝑛Tsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑛f_{n}(\boldsymbol{x}_{j,k,n},y_{j,k,n},\boldsymbol{w}_{k,n})=-\log\left(1+\exp\left(-y_{j,k,n}\boldsymbol{x}_{j,k,n}^{\mathrm{T}}\boldsymbol{w}_{k,n}\right)\right). Hence, the loss function of device n∈𝒩k𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘n\in\mathcal{N}_{k} associated with edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} on dataset Dk,nsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑛D_{k,n} can be defined as

Fk,n​(𝒘k,n)=1|Dk,n|​∑j=1|Dk,n|fk,n​(𝒙j,k,n,yj,k,n,𝒘k,n),∀k∈𝒦,n∈𝒩k.formulae-sequencesubscript𝐹𝑘𝑛subscript𝒘𝑘𝑛1subscript𝐷𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐷𝑘𝑛subscript𝑓𝑘𝑛subscript𝒙𝑗𝑘𝑛subscript𝑦𝑗𝑘𝑛subscript𝒘𝑘𝑛formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘\begin{split}F_{k,n}(\boldsymbol{w}_{k,n})=\frac{1}{|D_{k,n}|}\sum_{j=1}^{|D_{k,n}|}f_{k,n}(\boldsymbol{x}_{j,k,n},y_{j,k,n},\boldsymbol{w}_{k,n}),\\ ~{}\forall k\in\mathcal{K},n\in\mathcal{N}_{k}.\end{split} (1)

The local update model of device n∈𝒩k𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘n\in\mathcal{N}_{k} in edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} can be achieved by

𝒘k,nt=𝒘k,nt−1−η​∇Fk,n​(𝒘k,nt−1),∀k∈𝒦,n∈𝒩k,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑛𝑡1𝜂∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑛𝑡1formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘\begin{split}\boldsymbol{w}_{k,n}^{t}=\boldsymbol{w}_{k,n}^{t-1}-\eta\nabla F_{k,n}(\boldsymbol{w}_{k,n}^{t-1}),~{}\forall k\in\mathcal{K},n\in\mathcal{N}_{k},\end{split} (2)

where η𝜂\eta is a predefined learning rate.

Define Ck,nsubscript𝐶𝑘𝑛C_{k,n} as the number of CPU cycles for local device n∈𝒩k𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘n\in\mathcal{N}_{k} associated with edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} to process one sample data. Assuming each sample data has the same size, the total CPU cycles to run one local iteration is Ck,n​|Dk,n|subscript𝐶𝑘𝑛subscript𝐷𝑘𝑛C_{k,n}|D_{k,n}|. We further let fk,nsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑛f_{k,n} be the computation frequency of device n∈𝒩k𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘n\in\mathcal{N}_{k} in edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}. In this way, the related local gradient calculation latency in one round can be formulated as

Tk,nc=Ck,n​|Dk,n|fk,n,∀k∈𝒦,n∈𝒩k.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛𝑐subscript𝐶𝑘𝑛subscript𝐷𝑘𝑛subscript𝑓𝑘𝑛formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘T_{k,n}^{c}=\dfrac{C_{k,n}|D_{k,n}|}{f_{k,n}},~{}\forall k\in\mathcal{K},n\in\mathcal{N}_{k}. (3)

II-A2 Local Model Transmission

We adopt the Orthogonal-Frequency-Division Multiple Access (OFDMA) technique for local uplink transmissions. Define Bk,nsubscript𝐵𝑘𝑛B_{k,n} as the bandwidth allocated to device n∈𝒩k𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘n\in\mathcal{N}_{k}. Therefore, we have ∑n=1𝒩kBk,n=Bksuperscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝒩𝑘subscript𝐵𝑘𝑛subscript𝐵𝑘\sum_{n=1}^{\mathcal{N}_{k}}B_{k,n}=B_{k}, where Bksubscript𝐵𝑘B_{k} is the bandwidth allocated to edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} for the transmission between edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} and the associated local devices. Meanwhile, we have ∑k=1KBk≤Besuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝐵𝑒\sum_{k=1}^{K}B_{k}\leq B_{e}, where Besubscript𝐵𝑒B_{e} is the total bandwidth allocated for the communication between edge nodes to the local devices. Therefore, the achievable local uplink data rate from device n∈𝒩k𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘n\in\mathcal{N}_{k} to edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} can be formulated as

rk,nu=Bk,n​log2⁡(1+Pk,n​gk,nBk,n​N0),∀k∈𝒦,n∈𝒩k,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘𝑛𝑢subscript𝐵𝑘𝑛subscript21subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛subscript𝑔𝑘𝑛subscript𝐵𝑘𝑛subscript𝑁0formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘r_{k,n}^{u}=B_{k,n}\log_{2}\left({1+\frac{P_{k,n}g_{k,n}}{B_{k,n}N_{0}}}\right)\!,~{}\forall k\in\mathcal{K},n\in\mathcal{N}_{k}, (4)

where Pk,nsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑛P_{k,n} is the uplink transmission power of device n∈𝒩k𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘n\in\mathcal{N}_{k} in edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, gk,nsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑛g_{k,n} denotes the channel gain between local device n∈𝒩k𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘n\in\mathcal{N}_{k} and edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, and N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} means the noise power.

Similarly, the achievable downlink data rate for device n∈𝒩k𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘n\in\mathcal{N}_{k} associated with edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} can be expressed as

rk,nd=Bk​log2⁡(1+Pk​gk,nBk​N0),∀k∈𝒦,n∈𝒩k,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘𝑛𝑑subscript𝐵𝑘subscript21subscript𝑃𝑘subscript𝑔𝑘𝑛subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑁0formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘r_{k,n}^{d}=B_{k}\log_{2}\left({1+\frac{P_{k}g_{k,n}}{B_{k}N_{0}}}\right)\!,~{}\forall k\in\mathcal{K},n\in\mathcal{N}_{k}, (5)

where Pksubscript𝑃𝑘P_{k} is the downlink transmission power of edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}.

In this work, we use the same training model for the whole communication system. Therefore, the number of model parameters in each level of model transfer has the same size. Denote Z𝑍Z as the data size of the model parameter bits. The local gradient upload latency of device n∈𝒩k𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘n\in\mathcal{N}_{k} in edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} can be expressed as

II-A3 Edge Model Aggregation

In this work, each edge node can receive the updated model parameters from its associated homogeneous devices. Since the devices under one edge node usually have a similar type, we adopt the synchronous aggregation method to average these updated models. It means that the edge node would wait for the slowest node to complete training in each round and collect all the connected devices’ updated model parameters. Therefore, the edge model aggregating equation for edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} can be formulated as

𝒘kt=∑n=1𝒩k|Dk,n|​𝒘k,nt|Dk|,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝒩𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑛𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦\boldsymbol{w}_{k}^{t}=\frac{\sum_{n=1}^{\mathcal{N}_{k}}|D_{k,n}|\boldsymbol{w}_{k,n}^{t}}{|D_{k}|},~{}\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (8)

where |Dk|=∑n=1𝒩k|Dk,n|subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝒩𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘𝑛|D_{k}|=\sum_{n=1}^{\mathcal{N}_{k}}|D_{k,n}| is the total number of data in edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}.

We omit edge model aggregation time due to its strong computing capability. Hence, the computation and communication latency between each edge k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} and the related local devices can be derived as

Tke​d​g​e=maxn∈𝒩k⁡(Tk,nc+Tk,nu+Tk,nd),∀k∈𝒦.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑒𝑑𝑔𝑒subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛𝑑for-all𝑘𝒦T_{k}^{edge}=\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{k}}\left(T_{k,n}^{c}+T_{k,n}^{u}+T_{k,n}^{d}\right),~{}\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. (9)

II-B Cloud Aggregation

Similarly, the cloud aggregation stage contains two processes, i.e., edge model transmission and cloud model aggregation. Particularly, the selected edge nodes upload their updated model parameters to the cloud for aggregation. The detailed processes are as follows.

II-B1 Edge Model Transmission

Edge nodes would upload their model parameters to the cloud after edge model aggregations. To ensure uninterrupted transmission from edge to cloud, we also adopt the OFDMA technique. Hence, the uplink data rate for edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} can be expressed as

rc,ku=Bc,k​log2⁡(1+Pc,k​gc,kBc,k​N0),∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑐𝑘𝑢subscript𝐵𝑐𝑘subscript21subscript𝑃𝑐𝑘subscript𝑔𝑐𝑘subscript𝐵𝑐𝑘subscript𝑁0for-all𝑘𝒦r_{c,k}^{u}=B_{c,k}\log_{2}\left({1+\frac{P_{c,k}g_{c,k}}{B_{c,k}N_{0}}}\right)\!,~{}\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (10)

where Bc,ksubscript𝐵𝑐𝑘B_{c,k} is the bandwidth allocated to edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} transmits to the cloud node, Pc,ksubscript𝑃𝑐𝑘P_{c,k} is the uplink transmission power of edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} to the cloud node, and gc,ksubscript𝑔𝑐𝑘g_{c,k} denotes the channel gain between edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} and the cloud node.

Correspondingly, the downlink data rate from the cloud node to edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} can be formulated as

rc,kd=Bc​log2⁡(1+Pc​gc,kBc​N0),∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑐𝑘𝑑subscript𝐵𝑐subscript21subscript𝑃𝑐subscript𝑔𝑐𝑘subscript𝐵𝑐subscript𝑁0for-all𝑘𝒦r_{c,k}^{d}=B_{c}\log_{2}\left({1+\frac{P_{c}g_{c,k}}{B_{c}N_{0}}}\right)\!,~{}\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (11)

where Pcsubscript𝑃𝑐P_{c} is the downlink transmission power of the cloud node, Bcsubscript𝐵𝑐B_{c} is the total bandwidth for the transmission between the edge nodes and the cloud. As we would discuss later, only parts of the edge nodes can be selected in each round. Therefore, we have the constraint of

∑k=1Kαk​Bc,k≤Bc,superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝐵𝑐𝑘subscript𝐵𝑐\sum_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k}B_{c,k}\leq B_{c}, (12)

where αk∈{0,1}subscript𝛼𝑘01\alpha_{k}\in\{0,1\}. Here, αk=1,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼𝑘1for-all𝑘𝒦\alpha_{k}=1,\forall k\in\mathcal{K} indicates edge node k𝑘k has been selected, and αk=0,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼𝑘0for-all𝑘𝒦\alpha_{k}=0,\forall k\in\mathcal{K} otherwise.

In this way, the upload latency from edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} to the cloud node can be written as

Tc,ku=Zrc,ku=ZBc,k​log2⁡(1+Pc,k​gc,kBc,k​N0),∀k∈𝒦.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑐𝑘𝑢𝑍superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑐𝑘𝑢𝑍subscript𝐵𝑐𝑘subscript21subscript𝑃𝑐𝑘subscript𝑔𝑐𝑘subscript𝐵𝑐𝑘subscript𝑁0for-all𝑘𝒦T_{c,k}^{u}=\frac{Z}{r_{c,k}^{u}}=\frac{Z}{B_{c,k}\log_{2}\left({1+\frac{P_{c,k}g_{c,k}}{B_{c,k}N_{0}}}\right)\!},~{}\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. (13)

Similarly, the downlink latency from the cloud node to edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} can be expressed as

Tc,kd=Zrc,kd=ZBc​log2⁡(1+Pc​gc,kBc​N0),∀k∈𝒦.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑐𝑘𝑑𝑍superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑐𝑘𝑑𝑍subscript𝐵𝑐subscript21subscript𝑃𝑐subscript𝑔𝑐𝑘subscript𝐵𝑐subscript𝑁0for-all𝑘𝒦T_{c,k}^{d}=\dfrac{Z}{r_{c,k}^{d}}=\dfrac{Z}{B_{c}\log_{2}\left({1+\frac{P_{c}g_{c,k}}{B_{c}N_{0}}}\right)\!},~{}\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. (14)

II-B2 Cloud Model Aggregation

Since these edge nodes correspond to heterogeneous local datasets, their model updated periods various. If we adopt the synchronous aggregation model, the latency for faster training nodes is unacceptable. On the contrary, the asynchronous method has shorter round latency, however, it requires several times of training rounds than the synchronous method. Therefore, in this work, we propose a flexible semi-asynchronous aggregation method by combining the merits of both synchronous and asynchronous methods. As shown in Fig. 2, the cloud node would select |𝒮t|=∑k=1Kαksuperscript𝒮𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘|\mathcal{S}^{t}|=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k} edge nodes with the fastest training round for model aggregation, where the set of selected edge nodes is denoted as 𝒮tsuperscript𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}^{t}. Slow nodes would wait for the next communication round to upload their models. Hence, under the semi-asynchronous aggregation method, we can achieve a balance between training accuracy and communication latency. The semi-asynchronous aggregation method can be written as

𝒘ct=𝒘ct−1+∑k∈𝒮t|Dk|∑k=1K|Dk|​(𝒘kt−𝒘ct−1).superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑐𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑐𝑡1subscript𝑘superscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑐𝑡1\boldsymbol{w}_{c}^{t}=\boldsymbol{w}_{c}^{t-1}+\sum_{k\in\mathcal{S}^{t}}\frac{|D_{k}|}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}|D_{k}|}(\boldsymbol{w}_{k}^{t}-\boldsymbol{w}_{c}^{t-1}). (15)

Also, we ignore the cloud model aggregation latency due to its strong computing capability. Therefore, the cloud-edge communication latency can be derived as

Tkc​l​o​u​d=Tc,ku+Tc,kd,∀k∈𝒦.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑐𝑙𝑜𝑢𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑐𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑐𝑘𝑑for-all𝑘𝒦T_{k}^{cloud}=T_{c,k}^{u}+T_{c,k}^{d},~{}\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. (16)

Towards this end, the one-round latency for edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} is given by

Tk=Tke​d​g​e+Tkc​l​o​u​d,∀k∈𝒦.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑇𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑒𝑑𝑔𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑐𝑙𝑜𝑢𝑑for-all𝑘𝒦T_{k}=T_{k}^{edge}+T_{k}^{cloud},~{}\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. (17)

II-C Edge Update Model

From Eq. (2), the local updated models are determined by their own characteristics. Since the non-iid devices that connected with one edge node have a similar characteristic, the edge aggregation models are heterogeneous. Therefore, if we directly use the cloud model to update the edge models, the personalities among edge models would be eliminated. Meanwhile, the accuracy of the cloud model would be decreased. Hence, we introduce a new edge update model based on [28], which defines a weight distance formula to represent the difference among different weight relatives as

d​i​s​t​(𝒘kt,𝒘ct)=‖𝒘kt−𝒘ct‖‖𝒘ct‖,∀k∈𝒦.formulae-sequence𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑐normsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑐normsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑐for-all𝑘𝒦dist\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{t}_{k},\boldsymbol{w}^{t}_{c}\right)=\frac{\left|\left|\boldsymbol{w}^{t}_{k}-\boldsymbol{w}^{t}_{c}\right|\right|}{\left|\left|\boldsymbol{w}^{t}_{c}\right|\right|},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. (18)

Intuitively, the larger of d​i​s​t​(𝒘k,𝒘c)𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑡subscript𝒘𝑘subscript𝒘𝑐dist\left(\boldsymbol{w}_{k},\boldsymbol{w}_{c}\right), the greater of the model difference.

Typically, deep learning networks that consist of multiple layers and each layer contains various amounts of weights can be adopted here. For simplicity, we use a small dataset to obtain the layer with the most obvious characteristics, which has been denoted as ℒ={ℓ1,ℓ2,⋯}ℒsubscriptℓ1subscriptℓ2⋯\mathcal{L}=\{\ell_{1},\ell_{2},\cdots\}. Thereafter, we introduce a parameter εksubscript𝜀𝑘\varepsilon_{k} to measure the difference between the cloud model and edge model k𝑘k, which can be formulated as

εk=1|ℒ|​∑ℓ∈ℒd​i​s​t​(𝒘kt,ℓ,𝒘ct,ℓ),∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesubscript𝜀𝑘1ℒsubscriptℓℒ𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑡ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑐𝑡ℓfor-all𝑘𝒦\varepsilon_{k}=\frac{1}{\left|\mathcal{L}\right|}\sum_{\ell\in\mathcal{L}}dist\left(\boldsymbol{w}_{k}^{t,\ell},\boldsymbol{w}_{c}^{t,\ell}\right),\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (19)

where 𝒘kt,ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑡ℓ\boldsymbol{w}_{k}^{t,\ell} and 𝒘ct,ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑐𝑡ℓ\boldsymbol{w}_{c}^{t,\ell} represent the weight of the ℓℓ\ell-th layer of edge model 𝒘ktsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑘\boldsymbol{w}^{t}_{k} and cloud model 𝒘ctsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑐\boldsymbol{w}^{t}_{c}. Meanwhile, |ℒ|ℒ\left|\mathcal{L}\right| is the cardinality of ℒℒ\mathcal{L}.

From Eq. (19), εksubscript𝜀𝑘\varepsilon_{k} increases with d​i​s​t​(𝒘k,𝒘c)𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑡subscript𝒘𝑘subscript𝒘𝑐dist\left(\boldsymbol{w}_{k},\boldsymbol{w}_{c}\right). To keep the personalities, the edge updated model can be derived by

𝒘kt←εk​𝒘ct+(1−εk)​𝒘kt,∀k∈𝒦.formulae-sequence←superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑡subscript𝜀𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑐𝑡1subscript𝜀𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑡for-all𝑘𝒦\boldsymbol{w}_{k}^{t}\leftarrow\varepsilon_{k}\boldsymbol{w}_{c}^{t}+(1-\varepsilon_{k})\boldsymbol{w}_{k}^{t},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. (20)

II-D Learning Procedure of the SHFL Model

Based on the definition of SHFL model, the training procedure of the SHFL model at the t𝑡t-th iteration proceeds as follows, which is also shown in Fig. 3.

  1. 1.

    Local model training and update: Devices in C-ITS train their learning model and calculate their local gradient as ∇Fk,n​(𝒘k,nt),∀k∈𝒦,n∈𝒩kformulae-sequence∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑛𝑡for-all𝑘𝒦𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘\nabla F_{k,n}(\boldsymbol{w}_{k,n}^{t}),\forall k\in\mathcal{K},n\in\mathcal{N}_{k}. After receiving 𝒘kt,∀k∈𝒮tsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑡for-all𝑘superscript𝒮𝑡\boldsymbol{w}_{k}^{t},\forall k\in\mathcal{S}^{t}, devices in the selected edge nodes update their learning model based on Eq. (2).

  2. 2.

    Local model upload: Local devices upload their concrete models to related edge nodes based on the local-edge bandwidth allocation scheme.

  3. 3.

    Edge model aggregation: After receiving local models, each edge node computes the average edge model based on Eq. (8). Since device types among edge nodes are heterogeneous, their edge model aggregations are semi-asynchronous.

  4. 4.

    Edge node selection and resource management: Based on the reports of edge nodes, the cloud node selects a subset of edge nodes 𝒮tsuperscript𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}^{t} with the fastest training round and determines the bandwidth allocation.

  5. 5.

    Selected edge model upload: The selected edge nodes upload their aggregated models to the cloud node.

  6. 6.

    Cloud model aggregation and broadcast: The cloud server aggregates the uploaded edge models, and then broadcasts the current aggregated model 𝒘ctsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑐𝑡\boldsymbol{w}_{c}^{t} to the selected edge nodes.

  7. 7.

    Edge model update and broadcast: The selected edge servers broadcast the updated model 𝒘ktsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑡\boldsymbol{w}_{k}^{t} to local related devices.

The procedure starts from t=1𝑡1t=1 and repeats the above steps until convergence.

III Problem Formulation

As discussed earlier, there exists a tradeoff between the training accuracy and the transmission latency. Therefore, our goal in this work is to find a balance between them to provide safety, efficiency, sustainability, and comfortable services for the SHFL based C-ITS framework.

According to Eq. (2), the local model Gradient-Norm-Value (GNV) influences the local model updating, which measures the data importance. The GNV of local device n∈𝒩k𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘n\in\mathcal{N}_{k} in edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} can be expressed as

𝒈k,n𝒘,t=∇Fk,n​(𝒘k,nt)=∑Dk,n∂fk,n​(𝒙j,k,n,yj,k,n,𝒘k,nt)∂𝒘k,nt,∀k∈𝒦,n∈𝒩k.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑛𝒘𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑛𝑡subscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑛subscript𝑓𝑘𝑛subscript𝒙𝑗𝑘𝑛subscript𝑦𝑗𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘𝑛𝑡formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘\begin{split}{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k,n}^{{\boldsymbol{w}},t}&=\nabla F_{k,n}(\boldsymbol{w}_{k,n}^{t})\\ &=\sum_{D_{k,n}}\frac{\partial f_{k,n}(\boldsymbol{x}_{j,k,n},y_{j,k,n},\boldsymbol{w}_{k,n}^{t})}{\partial\boldsymbol{w}_{k,n}^{t}},\forall k\in\mathcal{K},n\in\mathcal{N}_{k}.\end{split} (21)

With out loss of generality, we leverage the norm of GNV to present the importance, which can be written as

σk,nt=‖𝒈k,n𝒘,t‖2,∀k∈𝒦,n∈𝒩k.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑛𝑡superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑛𝒘𝑡2formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘\sigma_{k,n}^{t}=\left|\left|{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k,n}^{{\boldsymbol{w}},t}\right|\right|^{2},\forall k\in\mathcal{K},n\in\mathcal{N}_{k}. (22)

Since an edge node connects homogeneous local devices, the GNVs among these local devices are approximately equal. Moreover, local devices in one edge node also have similar training duration, hence, all of these training models (GNV) would be uploaded. In this way, the GNV of edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} can be defined as

σkt=∑n=1𝒩kσk,nt,∀k∈𝒦.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝒩𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑛𝑡for-all𝑘𝒦\sigma_{k}^{t}=\sum_{n=1}^{\mathcal{N}_{k}}\sigma_{k,n}^{t},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. (23)

On the contrary, the cloud node associates with heterogeneous edge nodes, the GNVs among them various. Intuitively, edge nodes with significant gradients have more contributions on model updating and convergence. Therefore, the cloud would preferentially select impactive edge nodes to upload their information for cloud model aggregation. Then, the GNV of the cloud model can be written as

σt=∑k=1Kαkt​σkt.superscript𝜎𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝛼𝑡𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜎𝑡𝑘\sigma^{t}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\alpha^{t}_{k}\sigma^{t}_{k}. (24)

For easy of expression, we remove the iteration t𝑡t in the following.

Now, we are ready to describe the problem formulation. The goal of this work is to maximize communication-efficient via joint edge node selection and resource allocation scheduling for a SHFL based C-ITS network. To accelerate the learning process, it is desirable to select more edge nodes with larger data importance. However, to shorten the communication and computation latency, it is better to upload as fewer edge nodes as possible. As a result, the objective function that represents the tradeoff between GNVs and transmission latency can be formulated as

min𝜶,𝑩𝒌,𝒏,𝑩𝒄,𝒌⁡(−ρ​∑k=1Kαk​σk+(1−ρ)​maxk∈K⁡αk​Tk),(​III​)subscript𝜶subscript𝑩𝒌𝒏subscript𝑩𝒄𝒌𝜌superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝜎𝑘1𝜌subscript𝑘𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝑇𝑘italic-(IIIitalic-)\displaystyle\hskip 11.00008pt\min_{\boldsymbol{\alpha,B_{k,n},B_{c,k}}}\left(-\rho\sum_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k}\sigma_{k}+(1-\rho)\max_{k\in K}\alpha_{k}T_{k}\right),\hskip 11.00008pt\eqref{mnbs}

subject to

∑k=1K∑n=1𝒩kBk,n≤Be,superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝒩𝑘subscript𝐵𝑘𝑛subscript𝐵𝑒\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sum_{n=1}^{\mathcal{N}_{k}}B_{k,n}\leq B_{e}, (25a)
∑k=1Kαk​Bc,k≤Bc,superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝐵𝑐𝑘subscript𝐵𝑐\sum_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k}B_{c,k}\leq B_{c}, (25b)
αk∈{0,1},∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼𝑘01for-all𝑘𝒦\alpha_{k}\in\{0,1\},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (25c)

where Bc=B−Besubscript𝐵𝑐𝐵subscript𝐵𝑒B_{c}=B-B_{e}, B𝐵B is the total bandwidth, 𝜶=[α1,α2,⋯,αK]T𝜶superscriptsubscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2⋯subscript𝛼𝐾T\boldsymbol{\alpha}=[\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\cdots,\alpha_{K}]^{\mathrm{T}}, 𝑩𝒌,𝒏=[Bk,1,Bk,2,⋯,Bk,Nk]Tsubscript𝑩𝒌𝒏superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘1subscript𝐵𝑘2⋯subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑁𝑘T\boldsymbol{B_{k,n}}=[B_{k,1},B_{k,2},\cdots,B_{k,N_{k}}]^{\mathrm{T}}, 𝑩𝒄,𝒌=[Bc,1,Bc,2,⋯,Bc,K]Tsubscript𝑩𝒄𝒌superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑐1subscript𝐵𝑐2⋯subscript𝐵𝑐𝐾T\boldsymbol{B_{c,k}}=[B_{c,1},B_{c,2},\cdots,B_{c,K}]^{\mathrm{T}}, and ρ∈[0,1]𝜌01\rho\in[0,1] is the weight factor that controls the tradeoff between data importance and transmission latency.

Obviously, (III) is a MINLP problem, which is NP-hard. In the following, we would introduce an ADMM-BCU method to find the joint edge node selection and resource allocation strategy.

IV Joint Edge Node Selection and Resource Allocation

As known to us, all of the steps in the learning procedure are independent with the optimal scheduling decision. Denote Tk′=maxn∈𝒩k⁡(Tk,nc+Tk,nu)+Tc,kusuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘′subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑐𝑘𝑢T_{k}^{{}^{\prime}}=\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{k}}(T_{k,n}^{c}+T_{k,n}^{u})+T_{c,k}^{u}, the original problem (III) can be rewritten as

min𝜶,𝑩𝒌,𝒏,𝑩𝒄,𝒌⁡maxk∈K⁡{−ρ​∑k=1Kαk​σk+(1−ρ)​αk​Tk′},subscript𝜶subscript𝑩𝒌𝒏subscript𝑩𝒄𝒌subscript𝑘𝐾𝜌superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝜎𝑘1𝜌subscript𝛼𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘′\min_{\boldsymbol{\alpha,B_{k,n},B_{c,k}}}\max_{k\in K}~{}\left\{-\rho\sum_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k}\sigma_{k}+(1-\rho)\alpha_{k}T_{k}^{{}^{\prime}}\right\}, (26)

subject to (25a), (25b), and (25c).

To solve the above min-max problem, we first denote X=maxn∈𝒩k⁡(Tk,nc+Tk,nu)𝑋subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛𝑢X=\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{k}}\left(T_{k,n}^{c}+T_{k,n}^{u}\right) and Y=maxk∈K⁡(−ρ​∑k=1Kαk​σk+(1−ρ)​αk​(X+Tc,ku))𝑌subscript𝑘𝐾𝜌superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝜎𝑘1𝜌subscript𝛼𝑘𝑋superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑐𝑘𝑢Y=\max_{k\in K}(-\rho\sum_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k}\sigma_{k}+(1-\rho)\alpha_{k}(X+T_{c,k}^{u})). By applying the parametric method [29], (26) can be transformed into

min𝜶,𝑩𝒌,𝒏,𝑩𝒄,𝒌,X,Y⁡Y,subscript𝜶subscript𝑩𝒌𝒏subscript𝑩𝒄𝒌𝑋𝑌𝑌\min_{{\boldsymbol{\alpha,B_{k,n},B_{c,k}}},X,Y}Y, (27)
subject to (25a), (25b), (25c), and
Tk,nc+Tk,nu≤X,superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛𝑢𝑋T_{k,n}^{c}+T_{k,n}^{u}\leq X, (27a)
−ρ​∑k=1Kαk​σk+(1−ρ)​αk​(X+Tc,ku)≤Y.𝜌superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝜎𝑘1𝜌subscript𝛼𝑘𝑋superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑐𝑘𝑢𝑌-\rho\sum_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k}\sigma_{k}+(1-\rho)\alpha_{k}(X+T_{c,k}^{u})\leq Y. (27b)

Nevertheless, (27) is still a unsolvable MINLP problem. We then introduce an auxiliary variable 𝜶~bold-~𝜶\boldsymbol{\tilde{\alpha}} to deal with the binary vector 𝜶𝜶\boldsymbol{\alpha} [30]. Thereafter, (27) can be reformulated as

min𝜶,𝑩𝒌,𝒏,𝑩𝒄,𝒌,X,Y⁡Y,subscript𝜶subscript𝑩𝒌𝒏subscript𝑩𝒄𝒌𝑋𝑌𝑌\min_{{\boldsymbol{\alpha,B_{k,n},B_{c,k}}},X,Y}Y, (28)
subject to (25a), (25b), (25c), (27a), (27b), and
𝜶−𝜶~=𝟎,𝜶bold-~𝜶0\boldsymbol{\alpha}-\boldsymbol{\tilde{\alpha}}=\boldsymbol{0}, (28a)
αk​(1−α~k)=0,subscript𝛼𝑘1subscript~𝛼𝑘0\alpha_{k}(1-\tilde{\alpha}_{k})=0, (28b)
0≤αk≤1.0subscript𝛼𝑘10\leq\alpha_{k}\leq 1. (28c)

Problem (26) is transferred as a convex problem with equality constraints now. Hereinafter, we introduce the Augmented Lagrangian (AL) method to solve problem (28) through penalizing and dualizing the equality constraints (28a) and (28b) as

min𝜶,𝜶~,𝑩𝒌,𝒏,𝑩𝒄,𝒌,X,Y⁡Y+12​ν​∑k=1K[αk​(1−α~k)+ν​λk]2+12​ν​∑k=1K(αk−α~k+ν​λ~k)2,subscript𝜶bold-~𝜶subscript𝑩𝒌𝒏subscript𝑩𝒄𝒌𝑋𝑌𝑌12𝜈superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝛼𝑘1subscript~𝛼𝑘𝜈subscript𝜆𝑘212𝜈superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘subscript~𝛼𝑘𝜈subscript~𝜆𝑘2\min_{\boldsymbol{\alpha},\boldsymbol{\tilde{\alpha}},\boldsymbol{B_{k,n}},\boldsymbol{B_{c,k}},X,Y}Y+\frac{1}{2\nu}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left[\alpha_{k}\left(1-\tilde{\alpha}_{k}\right)+\nu\lambda_{k}\right]^{2}\\ +\frac{1}{2\nu}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(\alpha_{k}-\tilde{\alpha}_{k}+\nu\tilde{\lambda}_{k}\right)^{2}, (29)

subject to (25a), (25b), (27a), (27b), and (28c).

Here, ν𝜈\nu is the non-negative penalty parameter, and 𝝀=[λ1,λ2,…,λK]𝝀subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆2…subscript𝜆𝐾\boldsymbol{\lambda}=[\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},...,\lambda_{K}] and 𝝀~=[λ~1,λ~2,…,λ~K]bold-~𝝀subscript~𝜆1subscript~𝜆2…subscript~𝜆𝐾\boldsymbol{\widetilde{\lambda}}=[\widetilde{\lambda}_{1},\widetilde{\lambda}_{2},...,\widetilde{\lambda}_{K}] denote the dual variable vectors correspond to constraints (28a) and (28b), respectively.

Nevertheless, (29) is still a coupled problem due to the multiply variables of Y𝑌Y, 𝑩𝒌,𝒏subscript𝑩𝒌𝒏\boldsymbol{B_{k,n}}, and 𝑩𝒄,𝒌subscript𝑩𝒄𝒌\boldsymbol{B_{c,k}}. Therefore, in this work, we propose a distributed ADMM-BCU algorithm that can iteratively approach a near optimal stable solution with low computational complexity. Specifically, during each iteration, (29) is decomposed into edge node selection and resource allocation subproblems, which aim to solve the blocks of {𝜶,X,Y}𝜶𝑋𝑌\{\boldsymbol{\alpha},X,Y\} and {𝜶~,𝑩𝒌,𝒏,𝑩𝒄,𝒌}bold-~𝜶subscript𝑩𝒌𝒏subscript𝑩𝒄𝒌\{\boldsymbol{\tilde{\alpha}},\boldsymbol{B_{k,n}},\boldsymbol{B_{c,k}}\}, respectively.

The optimal edge node selection {𝜶,X,Y}𝜶𝑋𝑌\{\boldsymbol{\alpha},X,Y\}

Under the fixed resource allocations block {𝜶~,𝑩𝒌,𝒏,𝑩𝒄,𝒌}bold-~𝜶subscript𝑩𝒌𝒏subscript𝑩𝒄𝒌\left\{\boldsymbol{\widetilde{\alpha}},\boldsymbol{B_{k,n}},\boldsymbol{B_{c,k}}\right\}, the edge node selection optimization subproblem over the variable block {𝜶,X,Y}𝜶𝑋𝑌\{\boldsymbol{\alpha},X,Y\} can be rewritten as

min𝜶,X,Y⁡Y+12​ν​∑k=1K[αk​(1−α~k)+ν​λk]2+12​ν​∑k=1K(αk−α~k+ν​λ~k)2,subscript𝜶𝑋𝑌𝑌12𝜈superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝛼𝑘1subscript~𝛼𝑘𝜈subscript𝜆𝑘212𝜈superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘subscript~𝛼𝑘𝜈subscript~𝜆𝑘2\min_{\boldsymbol{\alpha},X,Y}Y+\frac{1}{2\nu}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left[\alpha_{k}\left(1-\tilde{\alpha}_{k}\right)+\nu\lambda_{k}\right]^{2}\\ +\frac{1}{2\nu}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(\alpha_{k}-\tilde{\alpha}_{k}+\nu\tilde{\lambda}_{k}\right)^{2}, (30)

subject to (25b), (27a), (27b), and (28c).

Obviously, (30) is a convex problem, which can be solved by standard tools, such as CVX.

In what follows, we provide the closed form expression of the optimal edge node selection by introducing Lemma 1.

From Lemma 1, we find that the edge node selection is mainly determined by the edge node importance σksubscript𝜎𝑘\sigma_{k} and the uplink transmission latency from edge k𝑘k to the cloud Tc,kusubscriptsuperscript𝑇𝑢𝑐𝑘T^{u}_{c,k}. Intuitively, the cloud preferentially selects the edge node with either a larger edge node importance or a smaller uplink transmission latency that can improve the communication-efficiency.

(36)

From Eq. (36), the optimal local-edge bandwidth allocation Bk,n∗superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘𝑛B_{k,n}^{*} is mainly influenced by the related channel conditions Pk,n​gk,nN0subscript𝑃𝑘𝑛subscript𝑔𝑘𝑛subscript𝑁0\frac{P_{k,n}g_{k,n}}{N_{0}}.

(39)

Obviously, the optimal edge-cloud uplink bandwidth allocation Bc,k∗superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑐𝑘B_{c,k}^{*} has a similar rule with Bk,n∗superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘𝑛B_{k,n}^{*}.

V Numerical Results

In this section, we conduct experiments to evaluate the theoretical analyses and test the performance of the proposed algorithm.

V-A Experiment Settings

CNN model settings: For exposition, we consider the learning task of training image classifiers, which are implemented on a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model, namely VGGNet 161616 [31]. The corresponding training dataset is CIFAR-10, which contains 500005000050000 training images and 100001000010000 testing images with 101010 categories. To simulate the distributions of heterogeneous data based mobile devices, all data samples are first sorted by digital labels, and then divided into 100100100 shards of size 500500500 and each local device is assigned with 555 shards. The batch size of each local device is set as 505050 and the average quantitative bit number of each parameter is set as 161616 bits. In addition, we adopt the Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) optimizer, and the learning rate for the CNN model is set as 0.10.10.1. The computation frequency of each local device is randomly set between 222 GHz to 444 GHz.

Wireless communication settings: We consider a hierarchical SHFL communication network consists of one cloud node and 101010 edge nodes. Each edge node connects with two local devices. Both edge nodes and local devices are uniformly distributed under the coverage of the cloud node. The total bandwidth is set as 202020 MHz. Moreover, the uplink transmission powers of each local device and edge node are set as 101010 dBm and 242424 dBm, respectively. Also, the downlink transmission powers of each edge node and the cloud node are set as 101010 dBm and 242424 dBm, respectively. Furthermore, we utilize the transmission pass loss model of 128.1+37.6​log⁡(d​[km])128.137.6𝑑delimited-[]km128.1+37.6\log(d[\mathrm{km}]). Meanwhile, the noise power spectral density is set as N0=−174subscript𝑁0174N_{0}=-174 dBm/Hz.

In the ADMM-BCU algorithm, we set the non-negative penalty parameter ν𝜈\nu as 111. The minimum successive divergence threshold ϵm​i​nsuperscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚𝑖𝑛\epsilon^{min} is set as 10−4superscript10410^{-4}. In addition, the maximum iteration number of ADMM-BCU algorithm is set as 200200200.

V-B SHFL Performance

In this subsection, we present the convergence performance of the proposed SHFL model. We first introduce the following baselines.

  • •

    Random selection: Under this circumstance, CNN is implemented with random data selection, where both 555 and 888 edge nodes randomly selective conditions are respectively considered.

  • •

    Full selection: Under this circumstance, CNN is implemented by selecting all of the edge nodes.

  • •

    Normal edge update: Edge nodes directly use the broadcast cloud model as their updated model.

For simplicity, we assume the transmissions from the selected edge nodes to the cloud node are uniformly allocated, totally 555 MHz. Meanwhile, the transmission bandwidths from local devices to edge nodes are also set as the same, totally 151515 MHz. Moreover, we set the weighted factor ρ𝜌\rho under the proposed algorithm as 0.80.80.8. Fig. 4 shows the convergence performance of the proposed CNN based SHFL model. From this figure, we can find that the VGG-16 network starts to converge at about 707070 communication rounds for both the random selection scheme with 888 edge nodes, the Full selection scheme, and the proposed scheme. However, the random selection scheme with 555 edge nodes presents the worst convergence performance. Intuitively, it is because the more devices to be selected, the larger data information can be provided to the neural network, and thus faster convergence. Moreover, due to the non-iid datasets, each node has different contributions. Therefore, the random selection scheme may play a side effect on the whole model, leading to a decreasing model accuracy. Overall, the proposed algorithm shows a near to the full selection scheme convergence and accuracy, which can achieve better performance than the baselines that would be discussed latter.

Fig. 5 presents the performance influence from the edge update model. From this figure, we find that either the training accuracy or the training loss under the elastic edge update model is better than that of the normal edge update model. The fluctuation of these curves are mainly due to the non-iid data form. Therefore, we can conclude that the elastic edge update model is significant to keep the personalities of the edge nodes.

V-C The Scheduling Performance

In this subsection, we mainly verify the scheduling performance of the proposed algorithm.

In Fig. 6, we shows that the proposed ADMM-BCU algorithm has a fast convergence and a low computational complexity.

Fig. 7 illustrates that a tradeoff exists between data importance and the transmission latency. The value of ρ𝜌\rho starts from 0.40.40.4 to 0.80.80.8 under the step of 0.050.050.05. This figure shows that a large value of ρ𝜌\rho leads to higher data importance and longer transmission latency, and vise versa. Thus, the operators can select a suitable value of ρ𝜌\rho according to their specific requirements.

In Fig. 8, we present the performance among the number of selected edge nodes, data importance, and latency under various weight factors. Fig. 8(a) shows the number of selected edge nodes and total data importance in different weight factors under various algorithms. From this subfigure, the number of selected edge nodes increases with the weight factor ρ𝜌\rho. When the value of weight factor ρ𝜌\rho is small, i.e., the associated edge nodes are small, the proposed algorithm has a lower data importance than the random selection scheme. With the increment of associated edge nodes, the circumstance changes, which has been explained in Fig. 4. However, the full selection scheme always has the highest value of data importance at the cost of higher latency, which is shown in Fig. 8(b). Fig. 8(b) shows the full selection scheme suffers the highest latency, and the proposed algorithm has the lowest latency after scheduling. Intuitively, the transmission latency is much lower than the total latency, which means the data training time is huge. Moreover, the transmission latency may not meet the requirements of ultra low latency C-ITS devices. Under this circumstance, we can enlarge the wireless bandwidth by some resource management technologies.

VI Conclusion

This work proposes a novel SHFL framework that consists of local, edge, and cloud nodes to provide safety, traffic efficiency, and comfortable infotainment services for C-ITS. Specifically, homogeneous devices are allowed to associate with one edge node. Therefore, we adopt the synchronous aggregation model for edge nodes. On the contrary, for the heterogeneous edge aggregation models, we introduce a semi-asynchronous aggregation model for the cloud node, where parts of the fastest training edge models can be uploaded at each iteration. Moreover, we investigate an effective edge-cloud update method to keep the personalities of the edge nodes. For communication-efficiency, we propose a joint edge node association and resource allocation strategy, which illustrates a tradeoff between training accuracy and transmission latency. A distributed ADMM-BCU algorithm has been adopted to solve the proposed optimal MINLP problem. Numerical results show that our proposed scheme can accelerate the training process and improve the performance for C-ITS.
